The  financial  and  economic  crisis  has  forced  the  Government  of 
Mongolia  (the  Government)  to  embark  on  a  process  of  fiscal 
adjustment. This is primarily centered around expenditure restraint 
in  view  of  the  dramatic  worsening  of  prices  of  key  exports, 
dwindling  international  reserves,  and  increased  pressures  on  its 
currency.  The  Government  is  acutely  aware  of  the  pressure  the 
current  global  crisis  is  placing  on  Mongolia's  most  vulnerable 
citizens  and  has  therefore  asked  the  Asian  Development  Bank 
(ADB) to help safeguard achievements in the education sector and 
to  mitigate  any  negative  impact  of  the  crisis  on  the  poor.  The 
Project will support (i) financing of meals at preschools for children 
ages  2–5  to  protect  access  to  preschools  for  poor  children;  (ii) 
continuation  of  the  targeted  provision  of  textbooks  to  secondary 
school students from poor families; (iii) provision of block grants to 
schools  in  need  of  operation  and  maintenance  funds;  and  (iv) 
capacity building at the Ministry of Education, Culture and Science 
(MECS)  in  financial  management,  budgeting,  and  monitoring  and 
evaluation to enable MECS to better deal with budget constraints. 
The Project is in line with the $229.2 million standby arrangement 
of  the  International  Monetary  Fund  for  Mongolia  that  requires  the 
Government  to  maintain  a  tight  fiscal  policy  to  restore  fiscal 
sustainability, and advocates donor support to mitigate the impact 
of the fiscal adjustment on the poor. The Project complements the 
Social  Sectors  Support  Program  approved  in  June  2009  that  will 
support a comprehensive overhaul of the existing system of social 
transfer programs to better target these programs to the very poor 
while  conserving  fiscal  resources.  The  Social  Sectors  Support 
Program  will  introduce  proxy  means  testing  (PMT)  to  improve 
targeting of the provision of free textbooks and the Project will help 
MECS  operationalize  PMT  and  enhance  the  efficiency  and 
effectiveness of education service delivery. The Project is a sector 
intervention that will support the Government in addressing short-
term  financing  needs  and  continuing  longer-term  policy  reform  in 
the education sector.

Mongolia  ranks  high  among  comparator  countries  in  terms  of 
education  expenditures,  enrollment  figures  and  completion  rates. 
Achievements  in  expanding  access  to  preschool  and  basic

Maintaining access to education for the poor and ensuring quality 
education  services  during 
fiscal 
adjustments is a major challenge for the Government. Decreasing 
real wages and unemployment impede poor households' ability to 
provide  adequate  food  and  necessities.  Without  continuation  of 
assistance programs, poor households may be forced to withdraw 
their  children  from  school,  and  to  revert  to  inadequate  diets 
resulting  in  malnutrition.  The  likely  increase  in  dropout  rates  of 
school students is serious because of the significant risk that such 
students  will  not  return  to  school  even  after  economic  conditions 
have improved, or that they will not be able to catch up with their 
peers when they return. The Project's pro-poor approach will focus 
on  (i)  free  feeding  programs  at  preschools  to  ease  the  financial 
burden  on  parents,  and  to  provide  an  incentive  for  preschool 
enrollment  and  attendance;  (ii)  targeted  provision  of  textbooks  to 
secondary  school  students  from  poor  families  to  help  maintain 
school attendance rates; and (iii) provision of block grants to fund 
school  operational  cost  and  essential  learning  and  teaching 
materials in selected schools. 
 
The impact of the Project will ensure that access to and quality of 
education  will  be  maintained  and  system  efficiency 
further 
enhanced during the time of the economic and financial crisis and 
thereafter.  The  outcome  is  adequate  financing  of  textbooks,  free 
feeding  programs  at  preschools,  and  school  operation  costs  in 
school year (SY) 2009/10 and 2010/11; and improved efficiency of 
the education sector.

THE PROPOSAL 

1. 
I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed grant to 
Mongolia  for  the  Education  for  the  Poor—Financial  Crisis  Response  Project.  The  design  and 
monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 

II. 

RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES  

A. 

Performance Indicators and Analysis 

2. 
The  Macroeconomic  Context  and  its  Social  Impact.  Mongolia  has  made  significant 
economic  progress  since  its  transition  from  socialism  in  1992.  Fundamental  economic  reforms 
have been undertaken in the areas of price liberalization and privatization, giving Mongolia one of 
the least restrictive trade regimes in Asia, and a relatively liberal foreign investment environment. 
The  country’s  vast  mineral  resources,  notably  copper,  have  attracted  significant  direct  foreign 
investment  and  created  substantial  revenue  flows.  Increased  budget  revenues  allowed  the 
Government  of  Mongolia  (the  Government)  to  implement  large  wage  increases  and  introduce 
untargeted  social  transfers.  Despite  economic  growth  across  diverse  sectors,  Mongolia  remains 
highly dependent on mining, leaving the country vulnerable to fluctuations in commodity prices.  
 
3. 
Since  the  third  quarter  of  2008,  the  current  account  imbalance  has  been  under  pressure 
because  of  the  dramatic  fall  in  terms  of  trade  with  declining  export  revenues  from  minerals  and 
agricultural  products.  The  price  of  copper  fell  by  60%  to  $3,500/ton  in  March  2009  as  a 
consequence  of  rapidly  falling  demand.  Although  copper  prices  have  been  rising  again  very 
recently,  the  large  drop  in  mineral  revenues  had  an  immediate  negative  effect  on  the  fiscal 
account,  the  balance  of  payments,  and  the  Government’s  capacity  to  sustain  universal  social 
transfers.1 While revenue as a share of gross domestic product (GDP) is at 2005 levels, spending 
in 2009 is almost one-third higher, fueled in part by the distribution of universal social benefits. With 
one  third  of  Mongolia’s  population  still  living  in  poverty,  the  resulting  social  consequences  of  the 
crisis can be severe unless the Government is able to include special measures in its adjustment 
policies and response to this external shock.  
 
4. 
The financial crisis comes in the wake of severe spikes in food and oil prices in 20082  that 
triggered  an  inflation  rate  of  33%  in  May  2008,  much  higher  than  in  most  other  Asian  countries.3 
The  prices  of  wheat  (primarily  imported)  and  meat  (domestically  produced)  contributed  to  nearly 
half  of  the  overall  inflation.4 Rising  food  and  fuel  prices  and  high  inflation  negatively  affected  the 
poor and vulnerable more than other population groups. The International Monetary Fund has set a 
target for the current account deficit in 2009 of around 6.5% of GDP, which can only be achieved if 
the  Government  cuts  down  on  public  expenditures,  including  for  social  services.  A  detailed 
overview of the macroeconomic context is in Supplementary Appendix A. 
 
5. 
Social Impact of the Crisis. Mongolia is among the 29% of all developing countries highly 
exposed to the poverty effects of the crisis. This is due, in part, to the reliance on volatile mining

The Mongolia Country Poverty Assessment7 highlights several structural aspects of poverty 
6. 
that are aggravated by the crisis. These include (i) rising inequality—the strong economic growth in 
the  country  during  recent  years  has  not  translated  into  greater  poverty  reduction;8 (ii)  worsening 
spatial  inequalities—while  the  poverty  rate  has  declined  substantially  in  Ulaanbaatar,  it  has 
increased  in  soum  and  countryside  areas;  (iii)  insufficient  social  safety  nets  and  coping 
mechanisms in rural and urban areas; (iv) high reliance on social welfare benefits even before the 
crisis,  especially  on  the  Child  Money  Program; 9 and  (v)  households  having  difficulty  paying  for 
school  expenses.  The  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)-funded  Social  Sectors  Support  Program 
(SSSP)10 aims  to  support  the  Government  during  the  financial  crisis  in  terms  of  policy  reforms  in 
social services delivery, including education, health, and social welfare.  
 
The  current  financial  crisis  is  likely  to  result  in  increased  poverty,  the  magnitude  of  which 
7. 
will be determined by the length and depth of the crisis and the effectiveness of countermeasures. 
The  1997  Asian  financial  crisis  demonstrated  how  the  economic  slump  resulted  first  in  large 
increases  in  unemployment  and  poverty,  which  then  triggered  the  worsening  of  education  and 
health  outcomes.  When  poor  households  suffer  loss  of  income,  more  children  and  young  people 
drop  out  of school;  engage  in  child  labor;  and suffer  from  malnutrition,  stunting,  and  other  health 
issues.  The  lessons  of  the  1997  financial  crisis  indicate  the  need  for  substantial  government 
intervention  to  maintain  long-term  growth  and  social  stability,  and  to  minimize  cutbacks  in  social 
investments that are critical for education and health programs—despite shortfalls of government 
revenues  and  drying  up  of  private  capital  flows.  These  lessons  were  considered  in  the  design  of 
the Project (Appendix 1). 
 
Education  Sector  Performance.  Mongolia  ranks  high  among  comparator  countries  in 
8. 
terms of education expenditure, enrollment figures, and completion rates. Immediately before the 
breakup of the Soviet Union in 1990, Mongolia had a high gross enrollment ratio and adult literacy 
rate.  The  cessation  of  Soviet  financial  and  technical  support  had  a  dramatic  impact  on  overall 
education service provision, with the enrollment ratio falling to 81% in 1995. Since then, Mongolia 
has made notable progress reclaiming previous achievements in the education sector. In 2006, the

12. 
Budget  Cuts  in  Education. The impact of the financial and economic crisis on education 
was a decrease in the education budget and households’ ability to meet the costs of education due 
to  increasing  unemployment  and  poverty,  and  reduced  purchasing  power.  Funding  gaps  in 
education  existed  before  the  financial  crisis,  and  are  expected  to  have  widened  during  the 
economic  downturn.  The  2009  approved  budget  for  MECS  was  MNT432,480.5  billion.22 With  the 
onset of the crisis, the budget was amended to MNT396,532 billion or an 8.3% cut affecting both 
recurrent  costs  and  capital  investments. 23  In  the  recurrent  costs  segment  of  the  budget,  cuts 
included  (i)  salaries,  wages,  and  related  expenditures  (reduced  by  2.8%);  (ii)  other  goods  and 
services  for  line  items  including  electricity,  heating,  transportation,  and  stationery  (reduced  by 
22.3%);  and  (iii)  education  capital  budget  for  the  construction  of  schools,  dormitories,  and 
kindergartens  (reduced  to  18.9%).  The  budget  for  the  provision  of  textbooks  also  experienced  a 
major shortfall. The National Action Plan 2009–2012 stipulates that free textbooks will be provided 
for  all  students  and  the  Government  budgeted  approximately  $11  million  in  2009.  However,  less 
than $1 million is currently available from the national budget, amounting to a funding gap of $9.7 
million for 2009 and 2010. The overview of education financing is in Supplementary Appendix D.

Increasing  Malnutrition.  Although  MECS  does  not  monitor  education  indicators  by 
income,  interviews  with  preschool  directors  and  focus  group  discussions  (FGDs)  with  parents 
indicate  that  the  increase  of  22%  in  preschool  enrollment  has  been  mainly  because  of  children 
from poor families who previously could not afford to pay 50% of the meal cost. The poor already 
spend  a  much  higher  proportion  of  their  income  on  food  than  those  who  are  better  off,  with  the 
poorest  third  spending  as  much  as  60%  of  their  earnings  on  food. 25  In  Mongolia,  declining 
household purchasing power may lead to a declining nutritional status for children, thus affecting 
their ability to learn. According to UNICEF, rates of childhood stunting could increase by 3%–7% 
and wasting by 8%–16% during the financial crisis. A Mercy Corps Study (2008) on food security in 
Mongolia revealed that one third of households are food insecure and 20% of children are stunted. 
The primary determinants of food insecurity identified in this study are poverty, unemployment, and 
lack of job security. FGDs reveal that feeding and adequate nutrition have become a concern and 
that  many  families,  including  teachers,  have  only  one  hot  meal  per  day.  Feeding  programs  at 
schools and preschools is seen as an incentive for school attendance. Given the high proportion of 
children from poor families enrolled in preschools, financing preschool meals is considered a pro-
poor approach.

the  nomadic  lifestyle  in  many  rural  areas,  boarding  schools  play  a  critical  role  in  the  education

Expenditure  Survey  (2007–2008)  indicates  that  poverty  in  Mongolia  increased  from  29% 27  in

IV. 

PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, ASSUMPTIONS, AND RISKS 

60. 
Benefits.  The  Project  will  benefit  an  estimated  150,000  children  ages  2–5  by  providing  a 
free  feeding  program.  In  addition,  about  100,000  students  from  low-income  families  will  benefit 
from receiving free secondary textbooks in SY2009/10 and SY2010/11. Secondary school teachers 
will benefit from 74,000 teacher guides to be provided under the Project. Approximately 750 school 
principals will benefit from the training modules in school leadership and management. More than 
300  schools  and  boarding  schools  with  approximate  enrollments  of  150,000  are  expected  to 
benefit  from  the  block  grants.  The  most  significant  economic  benefit  will  come  from  preventing 
malnutrition among vulnerable and at-risk children, and maintaining current school enrollment and 
simultaneously  preventing  an  increase  in  school  dropout  rates  by  providing  essential  learning 
materials such as textbooks targeted at poor students. Reforms will also improve the targeting of 
government  subsidies  to  the  poor. Capacity  building  under  the  Project  will  include  enhancing the 
efficiency  of  budgeting  and  financial  management  in  education,  in  the  context  of  the  current 
financial crisis and beyond, and improving M&E to enhance transparency and efficiency of public 
spending in education.  
 
Social  Aspects. The initial social and poverty impact analysis identifies several key areas 
61. 
where  the  Project  will  benefit  the  poor  and  disadvantaged  groups.  The  Project  will  have  a  direct 
beneficial impact on about 250,000 students in preschools, and primary and secondary schools. At 
least two thirds of the beneficiaries will be children from poor families. Specific pro-poor and social 
development measures of the Project include (i) targeting textbook provision to children from poor 
families,  (ii) enhancing  access  to  preschools  by  children  from  poor  families,  (iii)  encouraging 
community and parental involvement in schools, and (iv) providing block grants for schools serving 
disadvantaged  student  populations.  The  Project  was  designed  through  a  participatory  process. 
During  implementation,  the  Project  will  maintain  broad  stakeholder  participation  in  its  activities, 
including  civil  society  organizations,  nongovernment  organizations,  and  parent  associations.  A 
summary poverty reduction and social strategy is in Appendix 11.  
 
62. 
Ethnic  Minority  Issues.  No  negative  impacts  on  indigenous  peoples  are  expected. 
Targeting approaches under the SSSP will be applied nationwide and benefit indigenous peoples. 
The  poverty  and  social  analysis  during  project  preparation  confirms  that  no  negative  impacts  on 
indigenous peoples will occur.  
 
63. 
Gender  Aspects.  Poverty  is  a  larger  factor  than  gender  for  education  participation. 
Mongolia has reverse gender disparity as girls outnumber  boys in schools in every aimag and in 
Ulaanbaatar. The disparity between boys and girls is highest in rural areas where dropout rates for 
boys  are  much  higher  than  for  girls.  Boys  are  expected  to  undertake  herder  roles,  while  families 
encourage  and  support  girls  to  enter  education  as  a  means  of  providing  for  themselves.  The 
poverty and social analysis conducted during project preparation included gender analysis. Access 
to  education  is  not  simply  a  women's  issue;  parent  involvement  in  education  is  important  and 
needs  to  be  encouraged  and  monitored.  The  Project  will  ensure  that  both  girls  and  boys  benefit 
from  project  interventions,  and  that  parent  associations  are  involved  in  developing  block  grant 
proposals. A gender action plan is in Appendix 12.  
 
64. 
Environmental  Aspects,  Land  Acquisition,  and  Resettlement.  The  Project  entails  no 
new construction. The Project will not have any adverse environmental impact and is classified as 
environment category C. No civil works is envisaged under the Project, and the poverty and social 
analysis  confirms  that  no  involuntary  resettlement  is  likely  to  occur.  With  no  planned  land 
acquisition, the Project is unlikely to trigger ADB’s involuntary resettlement policy.

A.  Link to the National Poverty Reduction Strategy and Country Partnership Strategy  
The Government of Mongolia (the Government) has adopted the Economic Growth Support and Poverty Reduction Strategy,a 
the  National  Action  Plan  for  2008–2012,b  and  the  Millennium  Development  Goals  (MDGs),  which  together  constitute  the 
Government’s development strategy. The Government considers strengthening the education system as an integral part of its 
(i) economic growth strategy, which aims to promote stable, private sector-led growth; and (ii) social strategy, which aims to 
improve  access  of  the  poor  to  stable  income  opportunities,  and  improve  the  quality  and  accessibility  of  social  services.  In 
2008,  the  Government  launched  a  long-term  National  Development  Strategy,  consistent  with  achieving  the  MDGs,  for  the 
period  to  2020.  Mongolia’s  National  Development  Strategyc  states  that  one  of  the  key  priorities  of  the  Government  is 
improving  the  quality  of  and  access  to  basic  education  and  health  services  in  order  to  support  employment  and  income-
generating activities and sustainable human development.  
 
The Government’s education policy is driven by the Education Sector Master Plan (ESMP) 2006–2015d and the Education for 
All  strategic  plan,  both  of  which  were  prepared  with  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  assistance.  The  ESMP  provides  the 
principal planning and policy framework for the education sector. It identifies improving education quality, and maintaining and 
increasing enrollment rates as part of the overall outcome to be attained by 2015.  
 
ADB’s country strategy and program update (2007–2009)e for Mongolia confirms the overall directions of the country strategy 
and  program  and  its  priority  focus  on  poverty  reduction  and  the  MDGs.  The  education  sector  road  map  of  the  country 
operations business plan 2009–2013 (under preparation)f identifies the need to improve education sector performance as an 
important issue. Over the past decade, good progress has been made in the education sector, partly as a result of effective 
working  relationships  between  the  Government,  ADB,  and  the  other  key  development  partners.  However,  the  progress 
achieved in expanding access to preschool and basic education, and the effective launch of the Ministry of Education, Culture 
and Science (MECS) program in shifting to a 12-year basic education system by reducing the school entry age to 6 years is 
likely  to  be  undermined  by  the  current  financial  crisis.  With  one  third  of  Mongolia’s  population  living  in  poverty,  unless  the 
Government is able to execute an orderly adjustment to this external shock, the resulting social consequences will be severe, 
potentially undoing the gains of recent years and threatening the attainment of the MDGs. Maintaining access to and quality 
of education services during the financial crisis is a major challenge for the Government.

1.   Key Issues  
Falling real wages, rapidly rising prices in basic foodstuffs, and rising unemployment have already had a severe impact on the 
poorest  and  their  ability  to  provide  adequate  food  and  other  necessities.  Without  assistance,  households  will  be  forced  into 
debt and may have to sell assets on which their livelihoods depend (herders are reported to be selling livestock to cope with 
the  crisis  and  even  nonpoor  families  are  taking  out  bank  loans  in  order  to  survive).  Householders  who  have  taken  out 
mortgage loans in foreign currency are affected by the impact  of currency devaluation on monthly repayment rates. Cuts in 
school  operating  budgets,  currently  at  about  20%,  have  resulted  in  many  basic  services  being  reduced.  The  results  of  54 
focus  group  discussions  (FGDs)  with  teachers  and  parents  in  four  rural  aimags  and  in  the  city  center  and  ger  districts  of 
Ulaanbaatar,  as  part  of  project  fact-finding,  suggest  that  electricity,  cleaning,  and  heating  costs  are  being  cut  back.  Some 
schools  are  predicting  that  current  operating  budget  cuts  will  mean  that  they  will  not  be  able  to  heat  schools  for  up  to 
2 months during the winter. In-service teaching training investments have been cut back, which is a serious problem when all 
schools are in need of training to cope with the new curriculum and syllabi, and the unfamiliar demands of educating 6-year-
olds. In a school survey covering 107 schools, 47% of schools openly confirm that they were attempting to claw back budget 
shortfalls by asking for increased parental contributions. Survey results, compared with a similar survey undertaken in 2008 
suggest  that  the  real  parental  costs  of  sending  children  to  school  have  increased  over  the  past  year.  Reduced  family 
purchasing power combined with the increased costs of sending children to school may lead to the withdrawal of children from 
school  and  increased  rates  of  dropout  and  absenteeism.  FGDs  also  report  that  many  families  are  now  reduced  to  one  hot 
meal  per  day  and  this  could  result  in  malnutrition.g  Common  conditions  of  malnutrition  and  ill  health  reduce  intelligence 
quotient  by  5  points  on  average,  and  result  in  increased  absenteeism.  Global  evidence  indicates  that  school  feeding  has  a 
positive impact on enrollment, attendance, retention, and improvement of gender balance. In-school meal programs have also 
been  shown  to  improve  cognitive  ability  and  educational  achievement,  particularly  when  supported  by  micronutrient 
fortification.  A  recent  study  in  five  countries  affected  by  the  global  financial  crisis  notes  that  coping  strategies  employed  by 
households  include  (i)  eating  less  frequently  and  less  nutritious  foods,  (ii)  health  seeking  behavior  has  turned  to  self

average figure conceals substantial regional differences in poverty with the western region in particular demonstrating poverty 
rates  of  more  than  50%.  Shifting  demographics  due  to  inward  migration  to  urban  areas  have  resulted  in  new  vulnerable 
populations  in  the  periurban  ger  districts  in  Ulaanbaatar,  Erdenet,  and  other  cities.  A  high  proportion  of  these  migrant 
populations has failed to register and thus cannot access social welfare programs. The crisis comes directly on the heels of 
the 2008 massive spikes in inflation (particularly for food items) provoked by the global food crisis. Social analysis carried out 
in  the  preparation  of  the  Food  and  Nutrition  Social  Welfare  Program  and  Project  demonstrates  that  the  poor  were  directly 
affected and immediately cut back on the quality and consumption of food, and reduce or eliminate expenditures for health, 
education, transport, and energy. Evidence from the 1997 Asian financial crisis clearly demonstrates that social sectors, if not 
strongly protected, are impacted and that the outcome can be long-term deficits in health and education, which are particularly 
detrimental for the youngest.  
 
The World Bank analysis of the Living Standards Measurement Survey of 1998 and 2002i found that the negative impact of 
poverty  on  school  dropout  rates  is  significant  at  every  level  of  schooling—even  at  primary  where  completion  rates  are 
normally close to universal—and  poverty  has the largest  effect on upper  secondary  dropouts. In  the current financial crisis, 
FGDs in rural aimags report an increase in secondary school noncompletion for boys as they leave school early to apply for 
jobs in mines before the jobs are taken by others. Poverty affects children’s education outcomes directly (out-of-pocket and 
opportunity  costs)  and  indirectly  (family  or  parental  background).  Education  quality  (measured  by  2006  and  2007  basic 
education examination results conducted by the Education Evaluation Center) is significantly lower in rural areas. One of the 
major causes of high dropout rates,  which is of specific significance to the poor, is the high and increasing parental cost of 
sending their children to school.  
 
The Mongolia Country Poverty Assessmentj highlights several important dynamics of poverty that will directly affect how the 
financial  crisis  will  impact  the  poor.  These  include  (i)  rising  inequality—despite  the  previous  overall  strong  growth  in  the 
country, this has not translated into increased poverty reduction;k (ii)  worsening spatial inequalities—although the decline in 
the poverty rate is highest in Ulaanbaatar, this is accompanied by significant worsening within soum and countryside areas; 
(iii)  reduced  social  safety  nets  and  insufficient  coping  mechanisms  in  rural  and  urban  areas;  (iv)  high  reliance  on  social 
welfare benefits, especially by the poor on the Child Money Program (CMP);l (v) difficulty in paying for school expenses and 
particularly  the  costs  of  textbooks,  school  stationery,  feeding,  uniforms,  transport,  and  contributions  to  school  operating 
expenses;  (vi)  inefficiency  of  the  health  insurance  system  for  the  poor;m  and  (vii)  poor  infrastructure  and  access  to  basic 
services  in  remote,  rural,  and  urban  ger  areas.n  Price  increases  in  basic  household  items  and  essential  school  stationery 
items have been greater in rural than in urban areas, and life in rural areas is becoming more expensive. This, in combination 
with a perceived lower quality of education and health services, triggers inward migration to aimag centers and urban areas, 
which  in  turn  creates  the  new  vulnerable  periurban  ger  populations  and  creates  double  and  triple  shifting  in  many  urban 
schools.  Almost  30%  of  schools  surveyed  indicate  that  they  did  not  receive  the  free  textbook  allocation  for  poor  and 
vulnerable children. Most schools indicate that in any case the allocation for poor students was insufficient to meet needs and 
in  addition  was  poorly  administered.  Improving  the  targeting  of  the  free  textbook  allocation  and  the  efficiency  of  the 
Government’s social assistance program, the CMP, will have a significant impact on the affordability of education by the poor, 
particularly in rural and urban ger areas. Starting from 2006, the CMP has provided MNT3,000 per month and MNT25,000 per 
quarter  to  all  children  aged  0–18  regardless  of  household  income.  Early  findings  of  the  ADB-funded  Participatory  Poverty 
Assessment and Monitoring Projecto indicate that these payments are an important source of income for very poor families, 
although the informal charges levied by many schools and the overall parental costs of education are too high for the poor, 
even with CMP support. Migration from rural to periurban areas has grown as migrants seek better education, health, other 
services, and income-generating opportunities. This has caused overcrowding in urban schools. High migration rates can also 
be  associated  with  poor  student  performance  in  soum  and  bagh  schools,  and  the  indirect  cost  of  schooling  in  relation  to

2.   Design Features  
While the Project aims to provide immediate support to the feeding program for preschools, secondary textbook provision to 
poor students, and school maintenance costs, it also recognizes that current social transfers in Mongolia are typically not well 
targeted on the poor. Take-up rates of social welfare by the nonpoor are higher than those of the poor. In fact, 70% of social 
welfare  beneficiaries  are  considered  nonpoor.p  The  current  free  textbook  program  aims  to  provide  20%  of  the  national 
textbook  requirement  free  of  charge  to  poor  students.  Unfortunately  the  program  is  widely  considered  to  be  inefficiently 
managed  with  considerable  access  by  the  nonpoor.  A  recent  World  Bank  study  concluded  that  only  9%  of  the  student 
population  benefited  from  free  textbooks  and  not  all  of  these  were  poor.  During  the  current  financial  crisis,  the  growing 
number of poor will find it increasingly difficult to maintain adequate food consumption and access to education. Similar issues 
of efficiency may also apply to the meal program at preschools. To address the issues of inefficient management and poor 
targeting,  both  of  which  could  undermine  the  impact  of  the  project  investments,  the  Project  will  (i)  increase  the  percentage 
allocation  of  free  textbooks  from  the  current  20%  to  40%  to  bring  textbook  support  in  line  with  the  current  national  poverty 
threshold  indicator  for  2008,  which  suggests  that  35.2%  of  the  population  are  poor;  (ii)  provide  for  intensive  monitoring  of 
meals at  preschools  and  secondary  textbook  programs  until  the  proposed  launch  of  proxy  means  testing  as  the  basis  for 
improved social welfare targeting; (iii) conduct a textbook cost reduction study aimed at identifying strategies to significantly 
reduce the costs of textbooks to both government and families (this will be linked to the development of strategies to ensure 
financial affordability and sustainability for textbook provision in the future, and be closely linked to planned primary textbook 
activities  in  the  ADB-funded  Education  Sector  Reform  Projectq);  (iv)  conduct  research  studies  to  (a)  develop  strategies  to 
improve the quality, provision, and cost-effectiveness of meals at preschools; (b) evaluate ways to reduce the cost of school 
uniforms; (c) encourage greater community involvement in school management; (v) provide block grants to schools including 
boarding schools serving poor children to ensure minimum learning conditions in schools; and (vi) provide consulting services 
to MECS for capacity building in the critical management areas of planning, needs-based budgeting, financial management, 
development of an effective education management information system, and monitoring and evaluation.  
 
Project  beneficiaries  will  be  students  enrolled  in  preschools  and  secondary  schools.  The  Project  will  benefit  an  estimated 
150,000  children  aged  2–5  by  providing  a  feeding  program,  thereby  ensuring  normal  mental  and  physical  development.  In 
addition,  about  100,000  students  per  year  from  low  income  families  will  benefit  from  receiving  free  textbooks  in  priority 
subjects  for  at  least  4  years  because  the  Project  will  require  an  increase  in  textbook  production  standards  to  upgrade 
durability to achieve a minimum 4-year book life, which will provide maximum cost amortization and reduced provision costs. 
At least two thirds of targeted beneficiaries will be children from poor families. More than 100 schools will benefit from the pilot 
implementation of the school block grants and an additional 200 schools may benefit in school year 2010/11 if the pilot proves 
successful. Protecting access to education, enhancing quality through textbook support to the poorest, and providing nutrition 
and block grants to needy schools are all investments in the health and future productivity of the poor and vulnerable groups. 
The  most  significant  economic  benefits  will  come  from  preventing  malnutrition  among  vulnerable  and  at-risk  children,  and 
maintaining  current  preschool  and  secondary  school  enrollment,  while  simultaneously  preventing  an  increase  in  school 
dropout rates and increased absenteeism by providing essential learning materials such as textbooks, which will be targeted 
at poor students, and ensuring minimum learning conditions.

SOCIAL ANALYSIS AND STRATEGY 

A.  Findings of Social Analysis  
Key  Issues.  For  the  targeted  beneficiaries,  social  problems  related  to  education  are  now  both  a  rural  and  a  periurban  ger 
phenomenon.  In  rural  areas  children  tend  to  be  left  out  of  upper  secondary  schooling  because  of  a  combination  of  lack  of 
access, poor quality education, and limited household affordability in the context of rising parental costs of schooling. Rural 
students in baghs and soums do not have equal access to upper secondary education because rural schools closed senior 
secondary  grades  during  the  reorganization  and  rationalization  reform  in  1997.  Provincial  center  schools  have  only  limited 
spaces.  Attrition  rates  are  significantly  higher  among  rural  children,  and  education  quality,  measured  by  exam  results,  is 
significantly  worse  in  rural  schools.  Poverty  directly,  through  out-of-pocket  and  opportunity  costs,  and  indirectly,  through 
parental background, contributes to dropout rates. Rural students who tend to perform worse and drop out after the 8th grade 
are highly likely to be poor. High dropout rates are a concern because of their long-term implications for the intergenerational 
transmission of poverty. Second, the implementing systems for teacher incentives, resource allocation, and public assistance 
to  rural  schools  have  shortcomings.  An  assessment  of  the  outcomes  from  the  rationalization  and  reorganization  reform 
indicates that the reform effort seems to have perpetuated the widening gaps in education outcomes between urban (aimag

School-age migrant children are more than three times as likely to be out of school than children of permanent residents. A 
third of migrant children have dropped out of their schools mainly because of registration problems, discrimination at school, 
high  costs  in  sending  children  to  school,  and  family  poverty.  This  situation  not  only  contradicts  the  expectations  of  many 
migrants, who came to the city to get their children a better education, but also negatively affects the quality of education in 
areas  of  both  origin  and  destination.  If  the  trend  continues,  it  will  create  serious  burdens  on  the  capital  city’s  schooling, 
housing, infrastructure, environment, and social services. If the impacts of migration are not considered more systematically, 
national goals for access to education will probably not be achieved.   
 
The  current  financial  crisis  has  exacerbated  all  of  these  problems.  Falling  parental  purchasing  power,  static  or  declining 
incomes, increased costs of access to schooling, and higher costs and lower education quality in rural areas have already had 
an impact on access to education, on the quality of education, and on child and family nutrition. Inward migration is likely to 
increase  during  the  crisis,  which  will  create  further  stresses  on  urban  schools  already  stretched  to  a  maximum.  Improved 
access to a good education for rural students is a priority for equitable and sustainable development in Mongolia. Therefore, 
the Project will assist the Government directly to improve access for rural and urban children, including (i) reducing costs for 
parents; (ii) providing incentives for attendance; (iii) improving targeting of education subsidies; (iv) increasing the efficiency of 
planning  and  budgeting,  financial  management,  data  collection,  and  monitoring  and  evaluation;  (v)  providing  school  block 
grants; and (vi) improving the availability and usage of key quality inputs into the education system.

C.  Gender and Development 
1.  Key  Issues. According to the ADB-World Bank Mongolia country gender assessment (2005),s more girls than boys are 
enrolled  in  school  in  every  aimag,  including  Ulaanbaatar  city.  This  pattern  emerged  in  the  immediate  posttransition  period, 
although the gap has narrowed in recent years. Dropout rates for boys at secondary schools are high among poor families in 
urban  areas,  while  in  rural  areas,  children  drop  out  even  from  primary  school.  The  gender  gap  is  particularly  noticeable  at 
higher  education:  women  constitute  80%  of  students  who  completed  secondary  education  in  a  survey  conducted  by  the 
United Nations Development Fund for Women-Economic Growth Support and Poverty Reduction Strategy. However, poverty 
incidence  is  higher  for  households  headed  by  women  than  by  men.  The  Household  Income  and  Expenditure  Survey/Living 
Standards Measurement Survey 2002/2003t indicates that the proportion of poor women (43.8%) is higher than the proportion 
of poor men (34.8%). Incidence of poverty of poor women is higher throughout the country: the proportion of poor women is 
41.6%  compared  with  27.8%  for  men.  However,  in  the  rural  areas,  the  differences  are  less  pronounced:  the  proportion  of 
women (48.4%) who are poor marginally exceeds the proportion of poor men (42.8%).

GENDER ACTION PLAN 

 
Enrollment  and  retention  in  the  education  system  is  more  a  factor  of  poverty  than 
1. 
gender.  Even  so  the  reverse  gender  gap  in  enrollment  and  attendance  rates  at  all  levels  of 
education is creating imbalances in achievements with significant economic and social impacts. 
Males  are  participating  less  in  education  at  a  time  when,  globally,  education  and  training  are 
seen  as  key  ingredients  for  educational  development  and  global  competitiveness.  Access  to 
education  is  not  limited  to  a  women's  issue;  parent  involvement  in  education  is  important  and 
needs to be encouraged and monitored.  
 
2. 
Government  provision  of  feeding  programs  at  preschools  has  contributed  to  equal 
access  and  enrollment.  Further,  the  ability  of  mothers  to  send  their  younger  children  to 
preschool  has  not  only  an  impact  on  their  children’s  future  success  in  primary  school,  but 
preschools also  free  up  poor  mothers,  especially  in  single-parent  households,  to  participate  in 
the  labor  market.  As  a  result  of  the  financial  crisis,  the  Government  is  experiencing  a  budget 
gap in the provision of meals at preschools and may be forced to roll back its feeding program 
at  preschools.  Reduced  feeding  programs  may  adversely  affect  boys  and  poor  women.  The 
gender  action  plan  is  designed  to  decrease  gender  imbalances  in  preschool,  primary,  and 
secondary  education.  It  aims  to  (i)  ensure  continued  provision  of  meals  at  preschools  to 
promote  equality  in  enrollment;  (ii)  assist  in  reducing  the  dropout  rates  of  boys  and  girls  in 
secondary  schools  by  targeting  textbooks  at  poor  rural  households;  (iii)  assist  in  reducing 
dropout  of  boys  and  girls  in  primary  and  secondary  schools  by  providing  block  grants  to 
maintain  education  quality;  and  (iv)  ensure  gender  sensitivity 
targeting,  planning, 
management, budgeting, and monitoring and evaluation in the education sector.   
 
3.  
Budget  and  Implementation  Arrangements.  The  action  plan  does  not  require  a 
separate budget, as it is integrated into the Project. Implementation responsibility lies with the 
Ministry of  Education, Culture and Science and  the project implementation unit (PIU). Specific 
activities,  such  as  ensuring  disaggregated  data  in  the  integrated  database  and  providing 
gender-sensitive monitoring of textbooks, meals at preschools, and block grants, are included in 
the terms of reference for individual consultants. The PIU in the Ministry of Education, Culture 
and  Science,  with  support  from  the  gender  specialist  in  the  Mongolia  Resident  Mission  of  the 
Asian Development Bank, will be responsible for coordinating and monitoring implementation of 
the plan. The implementation of the gender action plan is included as an assurance in project 
documentation. The gender action plan will be implemented from the fourth quarter of 2009 to 
early 2012. 
 
4.  
Monitoring.  Monitoring  and  evaluation  of  the  action  plan  will  be  incorporated  into  the 
overall  monitoring  and  evaluation  plan  for  the  Project.  The  PIU  will  be  responsible  for 
establishing  and  coordinating  monitoring  and  evaluation.  ADB  staff  with  expertise  in  gender 
issues will participate in the midterm review. ADB’s Mongolia Resident Mission gender specialist 
will provide support to the gender action plan and participate in the review missions.
